ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about spectrum

I learned functional analysis and have a better understanding of linear operators and their spectra, Hilbert and Banach spaces, Fourier analysis, and other related topics.  It s nice generalization of many parts of linear algebra.
If it is prof. Schlag teaching, you will learn a LOT more than a normal functional analysis course.

* This course covered introductory topics in functional analysis and Fourier analysis. 
* Taking this class also helped me review/reinforce concepts from previous analysis classes, especially considering that this was the first serious math class I enrolled in after returning from a gap year. The homework provided extensive practice in writing analysis proofs.
* Prof Schlag's lecture style is very interactive. He focuses explicitly on motivating definitions and proofs with problem-solving intuition/illustrative examples, and he often asks for student input as he presents results so that we think with him during the lecture. Furthermore, relative to other math classes I have taken there was much less hand-holding in terms of working out small technical details of proofs discussed in class. Altogether, I felt that taking this class pushed me to developed greater mathematical maturity and reevaluate the way that I thought about math.

We studied linear operators on Banach spaces and Hilbert spaces. We covered several important theorems, including the "big four" of Functional Analysis: the Hahn-Banach Theorem, the Open Mapping Theorem, the Closed Graph Theorem, and the Principle of Uniform Boundedness. We also covered various Spectral Theorems, in particular the Spectral Theorem for compact self-adjoint operators on separable Hilbert spaces.
I learned to think about where results in math come from. For example the intuition needed fully grasp a proof and how different results are related to one another.

We learned about Banach spaces and Hilbert spaces, focusing especially on lp and Lp spaces. A treatment of Fourier series and spectral theory. Major results included Hahn-Banach and the Spectral Theorem for Compact Self-Adjoint Operators.
Spectral theory, Fourier analysis, ergodic theory, functional analysis. So, a lot of analysis!

Basics on Banach and Hilbert spaces. Fourier series and ergodic theory. Spectral theory of bounded linear operators. Open mapping theorem, uniform boundedness principle, Hahn-Banach theorem. Overall, I feel that my general analysis skills have improved greatly throughout this course.

I learned about the properties of infinite-dimensional vector spaces.

I will mention that I missed several classes in the second half of the semester and didn't get as much out of it as I would have liked. (My final exam reflected this.) That's on me, though

Spectral theorem for Hermitian matrices in finite dimensions, norms in finite and infinite dimensions, convexity, Banach and Hilbert spaces, continuous linear functionals,  operators and their norms, the dual spaces of basic examples of Banach spaces, dual of a Hilbert space is isometrically isomorphic to itself, Schauder bases and orthonormal bases, Bessel's inequality, how to characterize that an orthonormal family is an ONB (e.g. via equality in Bessel's inequality), projection theorem, Gram matrix, Lagrange multipliers for minimization problems, the spectrum and the resolvent set (the former being compact, the latter open), the spectrum of a self-adjoint bounded operator, computing the spectrum of simple examples, examples of operators in infinite dimensions that have no eigenvalues in their spectra, range-kernel relations, the Fourier transform and its properties such as its nature as an isometric isomorphism between L^2(T) and \ell^2(Z), convolution and how the FT acts on convolution, decay of Fourier coefficients of functions of some differentiability class,  Dirichlet and Fejer kernels, Riemann-Lebesgue lemma, convergence of Fourier series: pointwise (Dini condition), uniform, and in  L^2(T). The big four: Hahn-Banach, principle of uniform boundedness, closed graph, open mapping.  Latter three based on Baire category in a Banach space. Hahn-Banach on real separable normed space, then extended to complex spaces. Applications of these fundamental theorems. For Hahn-Banach: supporting hyperplane, separation of a point from closed convex sets. Weak and weak* convergence. Characterization thereof in sequence spaces such as c_0 and \ell^2. Weak* compactness of closed unit ball in X^* if X separable (Alaoglu). Compact operators, their properties (closed under norm convergence, ideal under composition with bounded operators), examples (diagonal matrices, integral operators). Identity on a Banach space X compact if and only if dim(X) is finite. Spectral theorem for compact self-adjoint operators on separable Hilbert spaces.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I like prof Schlag. His explains everything really clear, and he is always friendly to students.

The course is pretty good.  Schlag is a very entertaining lecturer, although sometimes he moves a little fast.  However, when that happens, he is receptive to clarifying questions.  His psets are very time-consuming, so buckle up, but I think they do a good job of reinforcing material.  Prof Schlag also gives 'generous help' (his words) on the more difficult ones.  Psets are returned promptly, and grading isn't overly pedantic (although graders change year-to-year).

+ See (1).
- Prof. Schlag's lecture style is probably best suited for auditory learners, since much of what he says (e.g. when he discusses intuition) is not written on the board. As someone who is more of a visual learner, this required a bit of adjustment.
The course was fast-paced, but overall was very well-taught and fairly structured.
The strength of this course is the teaching and how Prof. Schlag does a great job at teaching ideas in math.

Strengths:
- Covered lots of material
- Engaging lectures
- Interesting problem set material
- Reasonable examinations

Weaknesses:
- Lectures were sometimes confusing, moving very quickly with unclear boardwork
It covers very broad materials, which is very good. But I think the overall flows can be more well designed.

Strengths: Professor Schlag's lectures are very well-motivated and extremely interesting. His homework problems are quite challenging, but also very fun to work through. I can't think of any weaknesses.

The homework was much more challenging than I had anticipated, but given that this was cross-listed as a graduate course, I suppose that shouldn't have been so surprising to me.
(In the end, I missed two p-sets)

This class was very challenging, but I'm not sure that detracts from how interesting it was. I think if the problem sets were slightly easier, I think I would've enjoyed the course more while I was taking it. It's hard to appreciate how interesting a class is or a professor is when you're bogged down by work, but to be fair my impression of the course changed quite a bit once I began attending office hours. Dr. Schlag is quite demanding but certainly very helpful. He is the primary strength of this course. That seems kind of silly because what else could the strength be, but I would say that the strengths of this course are much more due to him than the actual content itself, an assessment I would not give to many other math classes I've taken at Yale. Taught by another professor, I'm not sure I would have had a positive assessment of the course given how much time it ate up.
Strengths: clear, concise, meaningful. Weaknesses: analysis has annoying computations, but the pain can be alleviated using proper linear algebra and abstract notation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I like this course, and I would recommend to other students, but the workload is comparatively higher than other courses.

If a student has a free slot and is curious about further analysis, I'd recommend this course.  It nicely generalizes lots of things from linear algebra and uses real analysis for some cool results, which also have lots of applications if you're into physics or lots of other topics.  Definitely come to class because the course only sort of follows a textbook and includes many things not in the book.  If you want a low workload course you can easily stack onto whatever else you've got going on, then maybe look somewhere else, but if you're willing to sink time into something interesting, consider this course.
If you are not a math major and prof. Schlag is teaching, Id say take with caution. It will be very rewarding but also the workload is going to be pretty insane.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in developing a deeper understanding of analysis and are willing to commit substantial time to achieve that goal.
I would recommend this course to other students, as long as they have taken MATH 255/256, MATH 305 and MATH 320, and multiple courses in linear algebra beforehand.

This was my favorite math class I have taken at Yale because the material is great and Prof. Schlag teaches it so well. That being said, the material requires a lot of thought and time and the problem sets are very difficult.
Yes, I highly recommend this course to any math major. I learned a lot and found the material interesting.
Yes. If you want to have a taste on interesting analysis, you have to take this one with Prof. Schlag!

Absolutely, especially if Professor Schlag is teaching it. You will not only learn about the big theorems in functional analysis, but you will also learn more about the motivations behind them as well as their important applications. Professor Schlag's homework sets can be very challenging, but they are a lot of fun, and grading is fair. I think taking this course has greatly expanded my analysis toolkit.
Definitely, though I would make clear the coursework expectations.

I would recommend this course. I would not recommend that they take it concurrently with other difficult courses. It took a lot of my time but I genuinely feel like I am a better student of math after this course. Beyond just learning about functional analysis, I feel that I have improved my actual proof skills through this course, and for that I am grateful, even if I resented the amount of work this class took while I was doing it.
This class teaches you how to think. (Thinking is important.)
